metadata.subject: Cuba in its new stage: SWOT Analysis
metadata.sender: Fundacion Internacional para la Libertad (International Foundation for Freedom)

relationships.description: Reestablished diplomatic relations after 54 years of interruption
Venezuela provided substantial economic aid to Cuba, estimated at $13 billion annually at its peak
Diaz-Canel is Raul Castro's chosen heir to lead Cuba

transactions: Currency exchange at 24 pesos to 1 dollar

analysis.purpose: To provide a SWOT analysis of Cuba's economic and political situation for business decision-makers considering investment opportunities
analysis.significance: Comprehensive analysis of Cuba's economic potential and risks during a critical period of diplomatic reopening with the US

notable_quotes: The government of Raul Castro doesn't want a regime change but rather an improvement of the Communist model initiated in 1959.
In Cuba there are no impartial courts to which one can resort in the case of a dispute of civil law, much less criminal law.
Cubans have been accustomed to stealing from the State in order to survive, by swelling on the black market the product of that theft.
red_flags: Government keeps 94% of worker salaries in foreign investment deals
No impartial legal system for dispute resolution
Surveillance of foreign businessmen by security forces
Currency exchange rate disparity (official 1:1 vs parallel market 24:1)
Property confiscation risks from original owners

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion found in this analytical business report

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed or evidenced in this analytical report

public_knowledge.context: This appears to be an analytical report on Cuba's economic situation during the diplomatic thaw with the US, containing information that would be of interest to business analysts and policymakers

analysis.summary: This SWOT analysis report examines Cuba's economic and political landscape following the reestablishment of US-Cuba diplomatic relations in 2015, highlighting investment opportunities in tourism, infrastructure, and pharmaceuticals while warning of significant risks including political instability, legal system deficiencies, and economic challenges under the communist regime.
